Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: A Descriptive Grammar of Hakhun Tangsa

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A core communicative function of the clause includes identifying the participants in an activity. The amount and type of information that identifies "who did what to whom" can vary from language to language. In many languages a word or affix is used to indicate basic information on the person doing the action, i.e., 1st person (I, we) 2nd person, (you, you all), or 3rd person (he, she, they). In the northeast Indian language Hakhun Tangsa, if 3rd person acts on a 2nd person (he kissed you) or a 2nd acts on 1st (you kissed me), additional information, called inverse marking, must be added to the verb.
Inverse marking and other such distinctive features will be used by Krishna Boro to determine the place of Hakhun within the Tangsa family, which consists of over 30 languages, and the place of the Tangsa family within the Northern Naga branch of the Tibeto-Burman family. There are over 250 South Asian Tibeto-Burman languages but many of these are yet to be systematically documented and as a result the history of these languages remains unclear.

Under the direction of Scott DeLancey of the University of Oregon, Boro, who is himself a native speaker of a Tibeto-Burman language, will produce a comprehensive descriptive grammar of Hakhun Tangsa. The Hakhun grammar along with recordings and analysis will form a unique resource for the study of key grammatical features for reconstructing the language lineage of the Northern Naga languages.

The grammar will form the basis for a practical orthography and teaching materials for the Hakhun community. Krishana Boro will also train community members in language documentary methods so that they can continue language documentation in less accessible regions after the primary project is finished.

All materials created through this project will be archived at the Endangered Languages Archive.
.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcome of this research project is a description of Hakhun Tangsa, a Tibeto-Burman language spoken mainly in Arunachal Pradesh in India and in the Sagaing division of Myanmar. Hakhun Tangsa is a previously undocumented, undescribed, and unwritten language with no written literature. It is one of around eighty speech varieties known as Tangsa or Tangshang varieties spoken at Indo-Myanmar boarder. Some of these speech varieties are mutually intelligible, others are not. The Tangsa varieties are the minority languages in both countries and are endangered. The young generation, especially in India, prefer majority languages such as Hindi and Assamese over their native language for their daily communication, and are less fluent in their native tongue than the older generation.

This project has also generated good amount of linguistic and cultural resources that will last and will be accessible for generations. One such resource is collection of words, which reflect the physical and cultural world that Hakhun people live. The words are organized as dictionary entries and are recorded using audio recorders. Another resource is recordings of folk tales, narratives, procedures, personal accounts, and conversations. They have been transcribed and translated, and can be used for various purposes besides preservation, such as creation of written literature, story books for children, teaching materials, and so on.

Another significant outcome of this project is generation of interest and awareness in the community members regarding the importance of their language, and development of skill to work with and develop their language. Many Hakhun people who are socially and politically active have come forward and showed interest in developing their language and literature. Many of them actively participated in the discussion of issues like developing orthography to write their language. My consultants, who have been working with me for several years on their language, have picked up great interest to promote their language, have developed an understanding of the intrinsic value of their language, and have learned the basic skills for continueing the work on their language. They have learned to collect/record oral literature from elderly people and to write them down using an orthography based on roman script.

These outcomes – a grammar, collected linguistic and cultural resources, and interest and skill to work on their language – have put the Hakhun community in a much better place than any other Tangsa community to continue working for the development and preservation of their language and culture. Moreover, the lexicon, the grammar and the linguistic and cultural resources are also going to be useful for typologists, Tibeto-Burmanists, and anthropologists. This grammar is one of around ten grammatical descriptions which exist for around two hundred Tibeto-Burman languages of Northeast India, and the only grammatical description within the Norther Naga or Konyak subgroup of Tibeto-Burman languages. The grammar provides detailed description of the sound system, word classes, word structure, phrasal structure, clause structure and clause types, and clause combination. Some of its typologically interesting features are hierarchical argument indexation, inverse marking, and split-ergativity. Anthropologists may find the kinship system and its linguistic coding interesting. The grammar will be a great resource for diachronic morphological and syntactic comparision among related languages.
